JHU High in Federal Money
by James P. Herring
Hopkins is at the forefront of
federal research grants to
universities with 363 million
dollars, distributed among the
Applied Physics Laboratory,
School of Medicine, School of
Hygiene, and Homewood.
"Hopkins has a world-wide
reputation as one of the finest
research institutions in the nation," says Milton Cole, Sponsored Projects Chairman in
charge of grants to Homewood.
"Hopkins is seen as providing
an ideal atmosphere for
research."
APL heads the list of divisions receiving federal money
with $250 million in grants,
primarily from the department
of the Navy.
The Medicine and Hygiene
Schools gross $80 million, and
the Homewood campus
receives $13 million.

According to Cole, the $13
million in grants given to
Homewood is an "impressive"
figure considering the size of
the faculty. The major grants
distributed at Homewood are
handed out by two departments
of the government; the National Science Foundation
(NSF) and the National Institute of Health (NIH). NSF
contributes $3.1 million and
NIH about $4.6 million.
The remaining amount
comes from smaller agencies,
including National Aeronautics
and Space Administration
(NASA), the Department of
Defense, and the Department
of Energy.
Cole expects Homewood to
gross an even higher amount
this fiscal year.

research grants for three and

Buying a New Car?
Campus Digest News Service

College students who can afford to buy a new car are
definitely in the minority, as the
typical '83 car owner is 40.6
years old.
Sports car buyers are the
youngest (31), followed by subcompact purchasers (34.6).
Whatever their age, LincolnMercury manufacturers must
be pleased with the news that
'82 car owners listed their cars
among the top 10 of
satisfaction—first for a U.S.
carmakers since 1981. J.D.
Power & Associates of California is responsible for surveying
7,000 owners to find out how
happy they were with their new
car purchases.
Ford Motor Company also
took honors for the USA's best

selling car during 1983.
Heading the top-10 sales list for
the second year was the subcompact Escort.
General Motors Corporation
dominated the rest of the list,
with seven of the top 10 places
taken by a mix of large and
small cars. No American
Motors Corporation or
Chrysler Corporation vehicles
made the list.
Analysts confirmed what
many people probably already
knew: Small cars sold well in
1983 because most Americans
were limited to spending between $5,000 and $7,000—the
price of most subcompacts.
Older car buyers seemed to
prefer bigger cars, as the typical
car buyers of mid-sized and luxury cars in 1983 were 50.4 and

College Stores' Sales Increase
Campus Digest News Service

College stores represent one
of the country's top-ranking
retail growth markets, according to figures released by the
National Association of College
Stores.
The typical college store
averaged a 9 percent increase in
sales last year and showed a 35

percent increase over the past
four years.
The gains significantly
outscore retailing in general
through the last few years'
recession.
The survey included two-year
and four-year institutions, and
ranged from stores reporting
annual volume of less than
$500,000 to those with sales

above $3 million.
Course books increased
slightly as a percentage of sales
in most stores, contributing
from 50 percent of total net
sales in the larger stores to 70
percent in smaller ones. Over
the past four years, college
stores have steadily increased
their proportion of used books
sold.

Do Nothing, Get Nothing
Approach any student, ask him what's the
biggest issue on campus, and wait for a reply. It should be quick and to the point. Two
words, or four words at the most.
"The Hut."
"The Hutzler Undergraduate Library."
For the first time this year, Hopkins
students have shown that they're upset.
They're voicing their opinions because they
don't want the administration to take away
their treasured gathering place. Speaking up,
you might say. They appeared before Student Council. They attempted a protest
before Commemoration Day ceremonies.
And they even signed petitions—something
only candidates for student government do
this time of year.
For the first time this year, Hopkins
students have shown that they care. Yes, the
administration should leave the Hut alone.
Yes, the Hut is a nice place to meet both
socially and academically. Yes, the Garrett
Room would be a terrible alternative. But
did they ever wonder why they're really complaining? Probably not. If there were other
meeting places on campus—places providing
a similar atmosphere to the Hut—students
most likely wouldn't complain because there
would be other places to hang out. They
would be aware that there are more significant problems underlying the obvious one.
The MSE Library doesn't have enough
room, and the Special Collections Room is
one of many solutions to the rare book
dilemma.

So what they're really complaining about
is the lack of essentially everything on this
campus. But only a certain few care about
some place where people can pull all-nighters
and read magazines. They don't realize that
there are things far more important than
Hutian activities.
Students have to do more. Hopkins isn't
a single issue campus. And they simply can't
depend upon Student Council to accomplish
anything. So the only alternative is for
students to voice their opinions on other
issues; students must stop complaining
among themselves because whenever it
comes down to doing anything, they always
say, "I can't. I have other things to do."
Careerism is the problem at Hopkins.
Everyone's more concerned with what they'll
be doing after graduation than with what
they're doing now. Unfortunately, the administration, though they won't admit it, is
satisfied with that attitude. They can simply sit back, relax, and laugh at us.
That's what they're doing. They're
laughing at us.
So what's it gonna be? Will we complain
about the Hopkins social life? Will we complain about the placement office that
primarily caters to engineers? Will we complain about the muggings and the assaults?
Will we complain about more than one thing
this year? Or will we sit back and do absolutely nothing?
Except, of course, study.

Shame, Shame
To the Editor:
Where the hell is Campus
Security when you need them?
Within the past month, three
people, two of whom are close
friends of mine, were mugged;
one at gun-point, one at knifepoint, and the other by brute
force. In response to the
question—wWhere were you
when I was getting hurt?"—
their only response was "We
only have two cars." All of
those incidents occurred on
campus or a block away from
campus, an area covered by
Campus Security.
All Campus Security does is
hassle students. One of my
friends has been hassled a
number of times; either for not
being a student or for having
his dog do his duties in a
"restricted" area. Instead of
annoying students, why don't
they work on helping the
students by keeping this place
safe?
At 11:00 p.m. I find Joe Cop
pacing through the halls of
Gilman or in the snack bar stuffing his face. Why don't they
get off their butts and start doing something to stop these incidents? This campus is not that
big. It should not be hard to
keep it safe.
Finally, students are unaware
of these attacks because Campus Security likes to keep them
quiet. That is the stupidest
thing I have ever heard of.
If they keep them quiet, how
can we learn about them? How
can we learn where to and
where not to walk?
Campus Security better get
their act together.

A Disagreeable Night Thoreau Spent in Jail
by Michael Lorton
If you like Henry David
Thoreau, you won't like The
Night Thoreau Spent in Jail, a
play by Jerome Lawrence and
Robert E. Lee, being performed by the Vagabond Players in
•Fell's Point through March 4.
This Thoreau, played blandly
by Marc Nohe, is opinionated,
cantankerous, rude, and
disagreeable. The real Thoreau
probably had these qualities as
well, but this Thoreau is also
stupid, self-righteous, wholly
lacking compassion and any
emotion except self-pity; the
real Thoreau certainly was not.
The play is ostensibly about
one night in 1846 when
Thoreau, who refused to pay
his taxes on the grounds that a
portion of the money would go
to supporting the war in Mexico, was thrown in the Concord
(Massachusetts) jail. As one
might guess, not a lot happens
in the one night before someone
(in the play, his aunt) pays his
taxes and has him set free, certainly not enough for a threehour play. The play is padded
with snippets supposedly from
Thoreau's life.
The depiction of Thoreau
seems entirely wrong. He's such

Marc Nohe as Henry Thoreau talks to Fred Kennan, his jailmate.

a fanatic and so unthinkingly
so, it is hard to imagine an intellectual like Emerson (here
played aptly if stiffly by Bruce
Godfrey) having any respect for
him at all, or for that matter,
this hotheaded Thoreau failing
to despise the discursive Emerson. In life, Thoreau seemed
thoughtful and deliberate; apparently Lawrence and Lee
didn't find him dramatic

enough, so they rewrote him as
a kind of left-wing version of
William Jennings Bryant who
leaps up like a Jack-in-the-Box
at each new opportunity to talk
and thereby to make himself
look silly. He incessantly
patronizes his cellmate, Bailey
(Fred Kernan)treating him like
an idiot because he is illiterate;
he taunts Lydia Emerson
(Fredericka Courpas)about her

sexual frustration; when his
brother John (David Keltz)dies
of tetanus, he tortures Ellen
(Lisa Gibson), who loved John,
by relating all the grisly details
of the slow painful death. His
reward for these atrocities
against dignity: Bailey worships
him as the font of wisdom, the
Emersons think of him as

smirks and thunderous glances
of rage and virtually nothing in
between. This may not be
Nohe's fault; that is all the
script expects him to do.
Most of the rest of the cast

no part at all, players of

brother John, and Bailey do

roles. To whatever extent the
